ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: So many, understanding different perspectives, from the viewer to the acto to the producer.

I developed how to go above and beyond with my research in film studies and application of theoretical knowledge. Learned more about historic films (documentaries) the various definitions, styles, and their influence through time.

AMST 395 was a survey course of the most influential films in documentary film studies. We learned about the essential filmmakers (Errol Morris, Robert Flaherty, Robert Gardner, Dziga Vertov, Jean Luc-Goddard, Michael Moore, etc) and movements in documentary film and how their works and philosophies influenced each other. We also learned how to analyze these films through and critical historical lens.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: There are no weaknesses I believe the course is highly curated.

Strengths: The participation requirement was strictly enforced and the professor is beyond knowledgable when it comes to this craft.
Weaknesses: N/a

A true strength of the course was that Professor Musser allowed us the freedom to really explore and delve deep into the topics that interested us most. Professor Musser is clearly incredibly experienced, and just having the opportunity to learn from him was a highlight of the course. In terms of weaknesses, I would love to see even more female directors listed! I would also have perhaps appreciated a little more constructive feedback on my midterm.
While the seminar format is important, sometimes it was hard to get the conversation going. But, when the conversation picked up I learned a lot.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Of course. Great professor and great content
Yes! It was super interesting learning about the history of documentary and how its evolved over the years.

YES!!! Professor Musser is brilliant and you will get an education that otherwise you would not have access to because of his passionate teaching style and very forward teaching. He understand the importance of documentary filmmaking and as a student you truly are able to understand that this is within his realm of expertise from the moment you walk into class.

Yes! In fact, I cannot stop singing its praises. In a world that operates on images more and more each day, I believe that should be a required class for all Yale students. It was a wonderful way to get to learn the history of image-making and to learn how to be critical about the media/content we consume.
